JAY LACROSSE TEAM
TO MEET YALE
Hopkins Stickmen Out
Annex Championship
YALE DEFENSE STRONG
First Intercollegiate Match
This Year for Both
When Hopkins stick fans fill the
Homewood stadium tomorrow to
watch the Jay lacrosse twelve play
its first intercollegiate tilt, until the
final whistle, they will see practically unknown quantities performing.
Both Yale and Hopkins beat their
Alumni teams last Saturday, but
neither victory was impressive, nor
did they mean much from intercollegiate standards.
From up New Haven way
rumors persist that Stevens and
Gaston are mighty clever close attacks. Last Saturday, Purnell Hall,
with his two heavy goal defenders
Bernard and Love, held three great
attack men to two goals, only two
goals for McD,aniels, Biddison and
Robinson together. But it was a
case of experience against overwhelming odds of physical condition, and the latter won.
Yale started practicing way back
in February, to beat Hopkins. Some
reports say they used snow shoes
for the first few scrimmages in Connecticut snow, for the Eli's are determined to take the Jays into camp
So tomorrow's battle narrows down
to a test of clever stick handling
and experience.
Strong Defense

Hoffman and Henderson, the
other two Yale attackers, are rather
dark horses. Our Yale correspond.
ent says they played a steady game
last week, but were not far above
par. The Yale defense is another
matter. They held their Alumni
scoreless Saturday while the attack
piled up 8 points. What a fairly
green Jay attack can -do against the
Williams-Rumsey Flygare combination remains to be seen.
Young Turnbull has already
adopted the justly famous Doug's
style of attack work of feeding the
homes and backing up every shot.
With any other goalie besides Pop
Finn in goal last Saturday, the Jays
would have piled up at least a dozen
goals by their well-aimed bombardment of shots that were stopped at
the edge of the net. And Dotterweich had his hands full watching
Jack's passes.
Jay Offensive

Guild and Dukehart work per
fectly together from last season's
experience. Triplett and Packard
are rapidly getting the hang of
Hopkins offensive play to form a
smoothly running attack machine,
which in time will be bard to stop.
Hopkins has built up the most
enviable lacrosse record in this
country. Pioneers in the stick
game, they have continued to win
lacrosse crowns from the days when
the Intercollegiate League had five
members until today when nearly
every college in the East is fighting for the championship laurels.
And the motto of every knowing
stick mentor is "Beat FIopkins."
That's the first and main step.
Support

Last year the Jays had a bad
year, following three successive intercollegiate titles and an Olympic
team. Tomorrow is the first step
for another crown. It is up to the
undergraduate body to get out to
Homewood field tomorrow and
push their team on for another
championship.
(Continued on page 2, col. 4)

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 4, 1930

Vol. XXXIV, No. 43
T. GUTHRIE SPEERS TO
ADDRESS SUPPER CLUB
The regular monthly meeting of the University Supper
Club will be held on Tuesday,
April 8, at 6.30 P. M., in
Levering Hall. Mr. T. Guthrie Speers, of the Brown
Memorial Church, will talk on
"Militarism in the Colleges
and the R. 0. T. C."
After Mr.. Speer's talk, the
results of the election of the
Y. M. C. A. officers for the
coming year will be announced. The following men
have been nominated: For
president, Frey and Mount;
for secretary, Levy a n d
Corckran ; for treasurer, Sharretts and Linck.
The Cabinet decided that
the losing presidential nominee would automatically become vice-president.

GRAD STUDENT-FACULTY
AFFAIR BEING ARRANGED

HOPKINS NETMEN TO
JAY ELECTED TO
ENGAGE GEORGETOWN
A. C. C. E. OFFICE
College Comics Elect Jay to Open Relationships with Carnegie and Western Maryland
Executive Committee
The annual convention of the Associated College Comics of the East
was held at the Hotel Astor in New
York City on Friday and Saturday,
March 28 and 29. The Black and
Blue Jay was represented by McDorman, Ghent and Gettemuller.
At the convention held in the
Hotel Astor a year ago, Wood,
Kolb, Medenbach, Ghent, and
Gettemuller, represented the Jay.
At the opening meeting, there
were two speakers of prominence,
Mr. Chenery, editor of Collier's, and
Mr. Eggleston of College Humor.
Nineteen of the twenty-three members of the association answered the
roll call, and one more publication
was added to the list.
Meeting

The graduate student-faculty
committee reports that the interest
in the dinner and dance for graduate students and faculty of the
Homewood campus is well beyond
expectations. Tickets for admission have been selling even more
rapidly than was anticipated.

The national organization committee recommended that the Association publish a book of information concerning the benefits of
collegiate advertising through college comics than through College
Humor magazine and giving the
rates and circulation of the mem
ber publications. This was passed
by the convention and the Penn
Punch Bowl was appointed editor.
The question of employing a man
to take care of national advertising
was deemed impracticable. It was
decided that relations be continued
with College Humor as at present.

Entertainment

Elections Held

The committee at a meeting held
last Tuesday reported that both students and faculty are realizing that
the 11th will afford a time when
both may get together informally
and enjoy a program consisting of
entertainment varying from an excellent negro clog dance to a talk by
Dr. Easton which will be in the
lightest of views. Also during the
evening there will be the presentation of the J. D. Clark bowling cup
which was won by the Classics Department. From 9 o'clock on there
will be dancing. The committee
feels itself justly proud of the program that it has arranged and is
particularly encouraged by the interest of students and faculty. Due
to the size of the great hall in
Levering Hall only 120 tickets have
been made available.

Last year, the Penn Punch Bowl
was elected president, the Cornell
Widow secretary, the Hopkins
Black and Blue Jay treasurer, and
the Penn State Froth and Pitt
Panther as associate members of
the executive committee. This year,
the Yale Record was elected president, the Penn State Froth secretary, the Cornell Widow treasurer,
and the Columbia Jester and the
Hopkins Black and Blue Jay as associate members of the executive

Lecture and Awarding of
Bowling Tourney Featured
DINNER AND DANCE
Committee Reports Tickets
Selling Rapidly

Hopkins netmen launch their
1930 craft next Wednesday when
they meet Georgetown at Washington. This threatens to be one of
the hardest matches of the season,
as Georgetown boasts a tennis aggregation that promises to rival the
rank of their fine 1930 basketball
quintet.
Leading the Georgetonians is
Gregory Mangin, who ranks tenth
in the niational line-up of tennis
stars. Ably supporting him is
Dooley Mitchell, recent winner of
the Maryland State Senior Indoor
Tennis Championship and several
other players with enviable reputations.
In the past year the Hopkins
team depended to a great extent on
the winnings of the last three men
rather than the first three. Although
these regulars of last year halve
graduated, there . is an unusual
amount of promising material which
has just entered the University and
which bids fair fair to fill the gaps.
The team thus predicts a rather
close match, with Georgetown, perhaps, having the edge in the first
two or three places and Hopkins
in the last three places.
Competition

The Blue Jays have been practicing steadily for about a week,
but the final members of the team
have not yet been selected. The
competition is high, as about 25
men have reported as candidates for
the six or seven places. Helmholtz,
the captain, has announced that the
final try-outs for the team which
meets Georgetown will be held on
Friday or thereabouts. Results of
the match with Georgetown will
have a great deal to do with the
alignment of the men for the succeeding matches. It is expected that
Goldberg, Helmholtz and Gump
will head the list in Wednesday's
match with Lukevitch, Varrilo and
Feldman making strong bids.

JUNE WEEK PROGRAMS
NOW BEING ORDERED
Orders for the June Week
souvenir programs will be
taken in Levering Hall every
day next week from 12 to 1
p. m., beginning on Monday.
These will be the only official programs for June Week
and are selling at 75 cents per
copy. All those intending to attend June Week, should arrange for the purchase of
theirs immediately as they
will be attainable by order
only. The souvenir program is
an attractive affair. The cover
.is of blue leather, and displays
cuts of Gilman Hall and the
University seal. The inside of
the program has not as yet
been finally decided, but it will
contain pictures of the campus, names of the patronesses,
and other copy of interest.
Students should place their orders as soon as possible in order that the committee may
decide on the definite amount
to order.

BARNSTORMERS
HOLD MEETING
Sixteen Men Were Voted to
Club Last Sunday
CHANGES NEXT YEAR
"Pops" Swindel to Leave; Girls
To Take Female Parts
Sunday afternoon at a meeting of
the Barnstormers at "Pops" Swindel's house, fifteen men were elected
to the Club.
Men Admitted to Club

Five of those admitted were eligible only under the special merit
clause of the Barnstormers' constitution to give recognition to first
year men who showed exceptional
ability, or who did no able work
during one year's affiliation with
the Barnstormers. Four of these
men are Freshmen: Talbot Banks,
Lester Haas, Anthony Harding,
and Allen Erskine.
The other admitted under the
special clause, is a Junior who did
such admirable work that the Club
members admitted him. This is:
Earl Evans.
The other ten admitted to the
Club, having met the requirements
then their work for several years

JUNE WEEK COMMITTEE
PLANS BEACH PARTY

A pleasant surprise is in store for
those planinng to attend this year's
June Week affairs. The committee
has just announced that the big feature of all the festivities will be in
the form of a one-day beach party.
This affair will take place at Pinehurst-on-the-Bay on June 10, the
day before commencement.

Mullikin Honorary Member

Harold Mullikin was elected as
honorary member of the Club because of work he did in writing a
play which was finished too late
to be taken into consideration as
a possible presentation this year
but which can be used next year if
the Club then deems it adaptable to
the season.
This number taken in this year
is many more than have been admitted in a single year in the past.
The large number is because this
year's club felt that a large
nucleus was needed in view of the
many changes which will be made
next season.

Students will be able to go down
to the beach any time after 1 p. m.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
There is mourning and wailing
and gnashing of teeth in the tents
of the frosh on the campus of Gettysburg College; the Tribunal has
sentenced six members of the class
of '33 for crimes running the entire scale from conversing with coeds to high-hatting upper classmen—sentenced them to punishments that will best illustrate the nature of the misdeed and offer the
most effective warning against a
second offense of a similar nature.
One unlucky victim, who considered himself a "big man with the ladies," was forced to carry a wastebasket and a "beautiful red heart to
show that he wears his heart in the
right place for little golddiggers ; in
addition, he was compelled to decorate his charming contour with a
dress and to yell "I'm pretty hot"
at every twentieth step. Others who
availed themselves of the privileges
of upper classmen to keep their
hands in their pockets, (perhaps to
show that even the lowly frosh
might have a normal . college life of
doing nothing), and to walk on the
grass of the campus were obligingly
given bricks to hold in their hands,
and stilts to prevent their misguided and erring feet from injuring the tender blades of grass
that beautify the campus.

Senior Class of the University of
Minnesota are in deep mourning
over the untimely and unexplained
loss of their class totem, an ordinary red and white striped barber's
pole. The engineers are firmly
resolved that until said pole is
found they will neither shave, be
shaved or have their hair cut.

JAY LACROSSE TEAM
TO MEET YALE
Hopkins Stickmen Out
Annex Championship
YALE DEFENSE STRONG
First Intercollegiate Match
This Year for Both
When Hopkins stick fans fill the
Homewood stadium tomorrow to
watch the Jay lacrosse twelve play
its first intercollegiate tilt, until the
final whistle, they will see practically unknown quantities performing.
Both Yale and Hopkins beat their
Alumni teams last Saturday, but
neither victory was impressive, nor
did they mean much from intercollegiate standards.
From up New Haven way
rumors persist that Stevens and
Gaston are mighty clever close attacks. Last Saturday, Purnell Hall,
with his two heavy goal defenders
Bernard and Love, held three great
attack men to two goals, only two
goals for McD,aniels, Biddison and
Robinson together. But it was a
case of experience against overwhelming odds of physical condition, and the latter won.
Yale started practicing way back
in February, to beat Hopkins. Some
reports say they used snow shoes
for the first few scrimmages in Connecticut snow, for the Eli's are determined to take the Jays into camp
So tomorrow's battle narrows down
to a test of clever stick handling
and experience.
Strong Defense

Hoffman and Henderson, the
other two Yale attackers, are rather
dark horses. Our Yale correspond.
ent says they played a steady game
last week, but were not far above
par. The Yale defense is another
matter. They held their Alumni
scoreless Saturday while the attack
piled up 8 points. What a fairly
green Jay attack can -do against the
Williams-Rumsey Flygare combination remains to be seen.
Young Turnbull has already
adopted the justly famous Doug's
style of attack work of feeding the
homes and backing up every shot.
With any other goalie besides Pop
Finn in goal last Saturday, the Jays
would have piled up at least a dozen
goals by their well-aimed bombardment of shots that were stopped at
the edge of the net. And Dotterweich had his hands full watching
Jack's passes.
Jay Offensive

Guild and Dukehart work per
fectly together from last season's
experience. Triplett and Packard
are rapidly getting the hang of
Hopkins offensive play to form a
smoothly running attack machine,
which in time will be bard to stop.
Hopkins has built up the most
enviable lacrosse record in this
country. Pioneers in the stick
game, they have continued to win
lacrosse crowns from the days when
the Intercollegiate League had five
members until today when nearly
every college in the East is fighting for the championship laurels.
And the motto of every knowing
stick mentor is "Beat FIopkins."
That's the first and main step.
Support

Last year the Jays had a bad
year, following three successive intercollegiate titles and an Olympic
team. Tomorrow is the first step
for another crown. It is up to the
undergraduate body to get out to
Homewood field tomorrow and
push their team on for another
championship.
(Continued on page 2, col. 4)

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 4, 1930

Vol. XXXIV, No. 43
T. GUTHRIE SPEERS TO
ADDRESS SUPPER CLUB
The regular monthly meeting of the University Supper
Club will be held on Tuesday,
April 8, at 6.30 P. M., in
Levering Hall. Mr. T. Guthrie Speers, of the Brown
Memorial Church, will talk on
"Militarism in the Colleges
and the R. 0. T. C."
After Mr.. Speer's talk, the
results of the election of the
Y. M. C. A. officers for the
coming year will be announced. The following men
have been nominated: For
president, Frey and Mount;
for secretary, Levy a n d
Corckran ; for treasurer, Sharretts and Linck.
The Cabinet decided that
the losing presidential nominee would automatically become vice-president.

GRAD STUDENT-FACULTY
AFFAIR BEING ARRANGED

HOPKINS NETMEN TO
JAY ELECTED TO
ENGAGE GEORGETOWN
A. C. C. E. OFFICE
College Comics Elect Jay to Open Relationships with Carnegie and Western Maryland
Executive Committee
The annual convention of the Associated College Comics of the East
was held at the Hotel Astor in New
York City on Friday and Saturday,
March 28 and 29. The Black and
Blue Jay was represented by McDorman, Ghent and Gettemuller.
At the convention held in the
Hotel Astor a year ago, Wood,
Kolb, Medenbach, Ghent, and
Gettemuller, represented the Jay.
At the opening meeting, there
were two speakers of prominence,
Mr. Chenery, editor of Collier's, and
Mr. Eggleston of College Humor.
Nineteen of the twenty-three members of the association answered the
roll call, and one more publication
was added to the list.
Meeting

The graduate student-faculty
committee reports that the interest
in the dinner and dance for graduate students and faculty of the
Homewood campus is well beyond
expectations. Tickets for admission have been selling even more
rapidly than was anticipated.

The national organization committee recommended that the Association publish a book of information concerning the benefits of
collegiate advertising through college comics than through College
Humor magazine and giving the
rates and circulation of the mem
ber publications. This was passed
by the convention and the Penn
Punch Bowl was appointed editor.
The question of employing a man
to take care of national advertising
was deemed impracticable. It was
decided that relations be continued
with College Humor as at present.

Entertainment

Elections Held

The committee at a meeting held
last Tuesday reported that both students and faculty are realizing that
the 11th will afford a time when
both may get together informally
and enjoy a program consisting of
entertainment varying from an excellent negro clog dance to a talk by
Dr. Easton which will be in the
lightest of views. Also during the
evening there will be the presentation of the J. D. Clark bowling cup
which was won by the Classics Department. From 9 o'clock on there
will be dancing. The committee
feels itself justly proud of the program that it has arranged and is
particularly encouraged by the interest of students and faculty. Due
to the size of the great hall in
Levering Hall only 120 tickets have
been made available.

the Penn State Froth and Pitt

the executive committee. This year,

DINNER AND DANCE
Committee Reports Tickets
Selling Rapidly

Hopkins netmen launch their
1930 craft next Wednesday when
they meet Georgetown at Washington. This threatens to be one of
the hardest matches of the season,
as Georgetown boasts a tennis aggregation that promises to rival the
rank of their fine 1930 basketball
quintet.
Leading the Georgetonians is
Gregory Mangin, who ranks tenth
in the niational line-up of tennis
stars. Ably supporting him is
Dooley Mitchell, recent winner of
the Maryland State Senior Indoor
Tennis Championship and several
other players with enviable reputations.
In the past year the Hopkins
team depended to a great extent on
the winnings of the last three men
rather than the first three. Although
these regulars of last year halve
graduated, there . is an unusual
amount of promising material which
has just entered the University and
which bids fair fair to fill the gaps.
The team thus predicts a rather
close match, with Georgetown, perhaps, having the edge in the first
two or three places and Hopkins
in the last three places.
Competition

The Blue Jays have been practicing steadily for about a week,
but the final members of the team
have not yet been selected. The
competition is high, as about 25
men have reported as candidates for
the six or seven places. Helmholtz,
the captain, has announced that the
final try-outs for the team which
meets Georgetown will be held on
Friday or thereabouts. Results of
the match with Georgetown will
have a great deal to do with the
alignment of the men for the succeeding matches. It is expected that
Goldberg, Helmholtz and Gump
will head the list in Wednesday's
match with Lukevitch, Varrilo and
Feldman making strong bids.

JUNE WEEK PROGRAMS
NOW BEING ORDERED
Orders for the June Week
souvenir programs will be
taken in Levering Hall every
day next week from 12 to 1
p. m., beginning on Monday.
These will be the only official programs for June Week
and are selling at 75 cents per
copy. All those intending to attend June Week, should arrange for the purchase of
theirs immediately as they
will be attainable by order
only. The souvenir program is
an attractive affair. The cover
.is of blue leather, and displays
cuts of Gilman Hall and the
University seal. The inside of
the program has not as yet
been finally decided, but it will
contain pictures of the campus, names of the patronesses,
and other copy of interest.
Students should place their orders as soon as possible in order that the committee may
decide on the definite amount
to order.

Lester Haas, Anthony Harding,
and Allen Erskine.
The other admitted under the
special clause, is a Junior who did
such admirable work that the Club
members admitted him. This is:
Earl Evans.

JUNE WEEK COMMITTEE
PLANS BEACH PARTY

A pleasant surprise is in store for
those planinng to attend this year's
June Week affairs. The committee
has just announced that the big feature of all the festivities will be in
the form of a one-day beach party.
This affair will take place at Pinehurst-on-the-Bay on June 10, the
day before commencement.

Mullikin Honorary Member

Harold Mullikin was elected as
honorary member of the Club because of work he did in writing a
play which was finished too late
to be taken into consideration as
a possible presentation this year
but which can be used next year if
the Club then deems it adaptable to
the season.
This number taken in this year
is many more than have been admitted in a single year in the past.
The large number is because this
year's club felt that a large
nucleus was needed in view of the
many changes which will be made
next season.

Students will be able to go down
to the beach any time after 1 p. m.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
There is mourning and wailing
and gnashing of teeth in the tents
of the frosh on the campus of Gettysburg College; the Tribunal has
sentenced six members of the class
of '33 for crimes running the entire scale from conversing with coeds to high-hatting upper classmen—sentenced them to punishments that will best illustrate the nature of the misdeed and offer the
most effective warning against a
second offense of a similar nature.
One unlucky victim, who considered himself a "big man with the ladies," was forced to carry a wastebasket and a "beautiful red heart to
show that he wears his heart in the
right place for little golddiggers ; in
addition, he was compelled to decorate his charming contour with a
dress and to yell "I'm pretty hot"
at every twentieth step. Others who
availed themselves of the privileges
of upper classmen to keep their
hands in their pockets, (perhaps to
show that even the lowly frosh
might have a normal . college life of
doing nothing), and to walk on the
grass of the campus were obligingly
given bricks to hold in their hands,
and stilts to prevent their misguided and erring feet from injuring the tender blades of grass
that beautify the campus.

Senior Class of the University of
Minnesota are in deep mourning
over the untimely and unexplained
loss of their class totem, an ordinary red and white striped barber's
pole. The engineers are firmly
resolved that until said pole is
found they will neither shave, be
shaved or have their hair cut.
